children.name: make a mistake a2
children.definition: make a mistake/ˌmeɪk ə mɪˈsteɪk/ : mắc lỗi
examples: ▪ my spoken spanish was okay, but i kept making mistakes in my written work.
▪ don’t worry - everyone makes mistakes.:

children.name: get sth wrong b1
children.definition: get sth wrong especially spoken to make a mistake in something that you do, say, or write, especially when this has bad or annoying results:nhằm lẫn
examples: ▪ i’ve been here a year now, and my boss still gets my name wrong!
▪ you’ve got your facts wrong, mate - he doesn’t work here any more.
get it wrongdeal with something in the wrong way
▪ once again, the government has got it wrong.

children.name: go wrong x
children.definition: go wrong/ˌgəʊ ˈrɒŋǁ-ˈrɔːŋ/  to make a mistake at a particular stage in a process, for example, with the result that the whole thing is spoiled: mắc lỗi
examples: ▪ check your work again and see if you can spot where you went wrong.
▪ if you follow the easy step-by-step instructions, you really can’t go wrong.

children.name: slip up c2
children.definition: slip up/ˌslɪp ˈʌp/  to make a careless mistake, especially so that you lose some advantage, or spoil a chance that you had: mắc sai lần, mắc lỗi
examples: ▪ we’ll just have to hope that the other teams slip up.
chúng tôi chỉ hy vọng rằng các đội khác sẽ mắc lỗi
slip up on: sai xót ở
▪ he slipped up on just one detail.
anh ấy chỉ sai xót ở một chi tiết

children.name: blunder x
children.definition: blunder to make a stupid mistake, usually with very serious results: sai lầm ngớ ngẩn
examples: the government later admitted it had blundered in its handling of the affair.
he realized he had blundered by picking such an experienced player for the team.

children.name: goof x
children.definition: goof/goof up/guːf, ˌguːf ˈʌp/  american informal to make a silly mistake: phạm sai lầm ngớ ngẩn
examples: ▪ you really goofed up this time!
▪ some drivers admit they goofed. others blame anyone except themselves.

children.name: misjudge x
children.definition: misjudge/mɪsˈdʒʌdʒ/  to make a mistake about a person, situation, or amount by wrongly thinking that they are one thing when in fact they are another: đánh giá sai
examples: ▪ i’m sorry -- it seems i’ve misjudged you.
tôi xin lỗi dường như tôi đã đánh giá sai bạn rồi
▪ it’s easy to misjudge the speed of a car heading toward you
rất dễ dàng để đánh giá sai tốc độ xe hơi tiến về phía bạn
▪ in fact, the us generals had seriously misjudged the determination and endurance of the north vietnamese.
thực tế các chỉ huy mỹ đã đánh giá sai nghiêm trọng về quyết tâm và sức chịu đựng của nhân dân miền bắc việt nam

children.name: fall into the trap of x
children.definition: fall into the trap of doing sth to do sth that seems good at the time but is not sensible: mắc bẫy
examples: ▪ don’t fall into the trap of trying to be too clever.
▪ it is very easy for the mother to fall into the trap of offering the child only food that she knows the child likes.

children.name: mistake a2
children.definition: mistake sth incorrect that you do, say, or write without intending to: lỗi sai
examples: mistake in
we may have made a mistake in our calculations.
the most common mistake is to plant them too deep.
make a mistakethe lab must have made a mistake – this can’t be right.
correct a mistakeluckily i was able to correct the mistake before my boss saw it.
realize your mistakeas soon as he realized his mistake he turned in the right direction.
admit your mistakeit is better to admit your mistake and apologize.
mistakes happenwe’re very careful, but mistakes can happen.
a common mistakea common mistake is to imagine that dogs think like humans.
a little/minor mistakethe essay was full of little mistakes.
a serious/grave mistakethere was a serious mistake in the instructions.
an honest mistake(= a mistake, and not a deliberate action )thomas admitted he had broken the law, but said that it had been an honest mistake.
a silly/stupid mistakeyou need to be able to laugh at your own silly mistakes.
an easy mistake (to make)she looks like her sister, so it’s an easy mistake to make.
a spelling mistakeshe spotted two spelling mistakes in the article.
be full of mistakesthe article was full of mistakes.
it is a mistake to think/assume etc somethingit would be a mistake to assume that all snakes are dangerous.
there must be some mistake(= used when you think someone has made a mistake )there must be some mistake. i definitely booked a room for tonight.
be full of mistakes(= have a lot of mistakes )the report was full of mistakes.
be all a mistake(= used to say that a situation happened because of a mistake )he couldn’t bring himself to tell her it was all a mistake.
common errors
►do not say'do a mistake'. saymake a mistake.

children.name: error b2
children.definition: error a mistake - use this especially to talk about mistakes in calculating or in using a language, system, or computer: lỗi, sai sót
examples: an error occurred in the processing of your application.
error in
there must be an error in our calculations.
register : erroris rather formal and is mainly used when talking about computers or in some fixed expressions such ashuman error. in everyday english, people usually usemistake:
there must be amistakesomewhere.
make an errorwe made too many errors, and that cost us the game.
commit an errorformal(= make an error, especially a serious one )he knew he had committed a grave error of judgement.
have/contain an errorif the data contains errors, the results will be wrong.
find/spot/notice an errorhis accountant spotted several errors in his tax return.
realize your errorby the time she realized her error, it was too late.
correct an error(alsorectify an errorformal)we will rectify the error as soon as possible.
avoid errorshe resolved to learn from his mistakes and avoid similar errors in the future.
compound an error(= make it worse )he refused to listen to our advice, which compounded the error.
an error arises/occursformal(= happens )if an error occurs, you will have two more chances to re-enter your password.
a common errora common error which students often make when writing essays
a serious/bad errorthe police made a serious error, which resulted in a young man’s death.
a small/minor errorthe letter contained some minor spelling errors.
a glaring error(= very bad and very noticeable )there is a glaring error on page 10, where his date of death is given as 2053, not 1003.
a huge/monumental error(= very serious )it was a monumental error to attack from the north.
a grave error(= extremely serious, with serious results )he has committed a grave error.
a fatal error(= extremely serious, so that you are certain to fail )telling your staff they are not important is a fatal error.
an unfortunate erroran unfortunate error resulted in confidential information being released to the press.
a grammatical/spelling/typing erroryou lose marks if your paper contains spelling errors.
a clerical/administrative errorthe applications forms were sent to the wrong addresses due to a clerical error.
a factual error(= which includes a fact that is wrong )the article contains many factual errors.
a tactical error(= one that may cause a plan to fail )both parties have made tactical errors in the run-up to the election.
a random error(= one that is not like others or part of a pattern )this may seem like a random error, but in fact it is repeated once in every 5,000 samples.
human error(= errors made by people )automatic checks reduce the danger of human error.
computer erroran on-board computer error meant that the plane’s systems shut down for a few vital seconds.
pilot/driver errorinvestigators believe the crash was caused by pilot error.
sb’s past errorsformal if we fail to learn from our past errors, we are doomed to repeat them.
a margin of error(= the degree to which a calculation might be wrong )we have to allow for a small margin of error in the calculations.

children.name: slip x
children.definition: slip  a small unimportant mistake that is easy to make: sơ xuất
examples: make a slip
▪ don’t worry -- we all make slips from time to time.
▪ people doing this kind of precision work can’t afford to make the slightest slip.

children.name: slip-up x
children.definition: slip-up a careless mistake that may spoil a plan or process: sai sót
examples: this whole situation only happened because of a slip-up by the bank.
if we are going to win the contract, we can’t afford any more slip-ups.
the other team took advantage of the goalie’s slip-up.

children.name: mix-up x
children.definition: mix-up a careless mistake that causes confusion about details, for example someone’s name, the time of a meeting etc: nhầm lẫn, lẫn lộn
examples: ▪ the police have now returned mr sullivan’s car and apologized for the mix-up.
mix-up over
▪ there was a mix-up over the train times and i arrived two hours late.
mix-up in
▪ i’m afraid there’s been a mix-up in the booking - we were expecting you tomorrow.

children.name: oversight x
children.definition: oversight a mistake that you make by not noticing something or by forgetting to do something: sót, bỏ quên
examples: ▪ i’m sure it was just an oversight that your name wasn’t on the list.
▪ the bank apologized for the oversight.
▪ due to an administrative oversight, several members of staff did not receive pay checks this month.

children.name: slip of the tongue x
children.definition: slip of the tongue when you accidentally say a different word from the word you intended to say, sometimes with embarrassing results: nói lộn
examples: he quickly corrected his unfortunate slip of the tongue.
did i say ‘harlow’? sorry, i meant ‘harrow’. it was just a slip of the tongue.
when i said thursday, i meant tuesday. it was a slip of the tongue.

children.name: boob x
children.definition: boobbritish /boobooamerican  informal a silly mistake, especially one that amuses people: sai lầm ngớ ngẩn
examples: ▪ we labelled the pictures with the wrong names, but the boob was spotted by one of our readers.
make a boob/booboo
▪ whoops! i think i’ve made a booboo.

children.name: howler x
children.definition: howlerbritish englisha very bad mistake, especially one that shows you do not know sth, and that often makes other people laugh: ngớ ngẩn , “khỉ rú”
examples: he read out a selection of howlers from students’ exam answers.
photographers should be careful of making classic howlers, such as having a tree grow out of your subject’s head.

children.name: a bad decision that causes problems for you
mistake a2
children.definition: mistake sth you do or decide that is not at all sensible and causes you a lot of problems: sai lầm
examples: buying the house seemed a great idea at the time, but now i can see it was a terrible mistake .
make a mistakei just want to prevent you from making a terrible mistake.
learn from your mistakesi’m sure he will learn from his mistakes.
repeat a mistakewe certainly do not want to repeat the mistakes of the past.
a big/great mistakebuying this car was a big mistake.
a bad/terrible/dreadful etc mistakeit would be a terrible mistake to marry him.
a serious/grave mistakethe decision to take the money was a serious mistake.
a fatal mistake(= a very bad mistake, often one that ends something )his fatal mistake was to underestimate his opponent.
a costly mistake(= that costs you money or has a bad result )hiring him turned out to be a costly mistake.
it is a mistake to do somethingit is a mistake to try to see everything in the museum in one day.
make the mistake of doing somethinghe made the mistake of revealing his true intentions.
make the same mistake again/twicewe won’t make the same mistake again.

children.name: miscalculation x
children.definition: miscalculation a mistake caused by planning something badly, and being wrong about the expected result:
examples: ▪ the president’s election defeat was the result of his own miscalculations.
▪ i thought if i told mark everything, it would be ok. that was a bad miscalculation.

children.name: error of judgment x
children.definition: error of judgment formal a mistake caused by judging a situation or person wrongly: sai lầm
examples: in my opinion, appointing his son as chief executive was a serious error of judgment.
make an error of judgment
new, inexperienced members of staff are more liable to make errors of judgment.

children.name: be a bad move c1
children.definition: be a bad move informal if something you do is a bad move, it is a mistake because it puts you in a bad or dangerous situation: nước đi tệ hại
examples: ▪ he tried arguing with her. this was a bad move.
▪ perhaps her resignation wasn’t such a bad move after all.
it is a bad move doing sht
▪ it was a bad move letting him come here in the first place.

children.name: blunder x
children.definition: blunder a stupid mistake caused by not thinking carefully enough about what you are saying or doing, which could have very serious results: sai lầm ngớ ngẩn
examples: ▪ it seems to be another public relations blunder by the government.
▪ a series of management blunders: hàng loạt những sai lầm ngớ ngẩn trong viêc quản lí
make a blunder
▪ she stopped, finally aware of the terrible blunder she had made.

children.name: indiscretion x
children.definition: indiscretion  a rather bad, silly, or immoral action by someone, especially someone in a public position - often used to make the action seem less bad
examples: youthful indiscretion
▪ he dismissed his past association with racist groups as a youthful indiscretion.
commit an indiscretion
▪ she confessed that she had committed a minor sexual indiscretion.

children.name: a silly mistake that causes social embarrassment
put your foot in it c2
children.definition: put your foot in itespecially uk /put your foot in your mouthespecially us  informal to make a stupid mistake by saying sth that you should not say, for example because it upsets sb or because it is a secret: lỡ lời
examples: ▪ she’s a little weird isn’t she? oh no, have i put my foot in my mouth? is she a friend of yours?
▪ simon wanted to finish the conversation before he put his foot in it any further.

children.name: faux pas x
children.definition: faux pasformala mistake made by saying or doing something in a social situation that embarrasses other people: hanh động/ lời nói vô ý, nói hớ
examples: ▪ i asked her how greg was, which was a bit of a faux pas considering they’d just split up.
commit/make a faux pas
▪ it was at that party that i committed the faux pas of spilling wine all over the host’s wife.

children.name: gaffe x
children.definition: gaffe an embarrassing and stupid mistake made in a social situation or in public: sự hớ hênh
examples: ▪ when she realized she had mistaken him for his brother, she was horrified at her gaffe.
make a gaffe
▪ the minister is well known for making gaffes in his speeches.

children.name: a mistake in words written or printed
misprint x
children.definition: misprint a word or number that has been printed wrongly: lỗi in
examples: ▪ it can’t really cost £20 - it must be a misprint.
▪ in the last sentence, ‘unclear’ is a misprint for ‘nuclear’.

children.name: mistake a2
children.definition: mistake a mistake in words that are written, typed, or printed:lỗi sai
examples: ▪ if you make a mistake, just cross it out.
mistake in
▪ there’s a mistake in the address.
spelling mistake
▪ check your work carefully for any spelling mistakes.

children.name: error b2
children.definition: error a mistake in words that are typed or printed: sai sót
examples: ‘it says in this advertisement that the exhibition opens at 10.’ ‘that’s an error.’
typing error
she made very few typing errors.

children.name: typo x
children.definition: typoinformala small mistake in a piece of writing which sb has typed or printed:: lỗi gõ/ lỗi in ấn
examples: the article was badly written and full of typos.
i spotted a couple of typos in the letter.

children.name: slip out c2
children.definition: slip outphrasal verbif sth slips out, you say it without really intending to : lỡ miệng, buột miệng
examples: i didn’t mean to say it. the words slipped out.
